Controllers

Controller class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Controller(inputs_n: int, commands_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0, state_n: int = 0, initial_state: List[float] = None)[source]

This class represents a controller for an Agent. There are two routes to customising Controller or one of its subclasses:

  1. Using step_fun(dt, inputs, params, state). step_fun is a function which can be written anywhere in the code for your experiment and passed to a Controller when it is constructed. This will only work for relatively simple controllers.

  2. By creating a subclass of Controller, like RobotController, where you can add any attributes you need to by writing a new __init__ method (which should call super().__init__, so that attributes from Controller are inherited and set up correctly). In some cases, you may also need to override the step method of Controller (possibly using super().step to inherit existing functionality), and to add other methods to the class.

If you want to create a self-adaptive controller, then you can either create a subclass of Controller or - for relatively simple cases - you can implement an adapt_fun(dt, inputs_hist, commands_hist, params_hist) function and pass it into a Controller when it is constructed.

__init__(inputs_n: int, commands_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0)[source]
Parameters:

  • inputs_n (int) – The number of inputs expected by the controller.

  • commands_n (int) – The number of outputs (commands) that the controller is expected to return from its step method.

  • state_n – The number of state variables that the controller expects to be returned from its step_fun method.

  • initial_state (list[float]) – The controller’s initial state vector, if it has one. Defaults to None. Should be a list with state_n entries.

  • step_fun (a function) – The function which will be used to generate the controller’s outputs, given the inputs to the controller’s step method, the interval of time to integrate over, and any state and parameters the controller makes use of.

  • noisemakers (List of NoiseSource objects.) – A list of noise sources which will potentially affect the commands the controller outputs.

  • noisemaker_inds (List of integers.) – A list of indices of commands which will potentially have noise added to them. Any indices which are out of range in either the list of noisemakers or commands will be ignored.

  • params (list of floats.) – A list of parameters used by the controller. These parameters will be used in the controller’s step_fun function, which will be caused from the controller’s step method.

  • adapt_fun (a function) – A function wich can be used to adapt a controller, by changing its parameters. It only has access to the same data that the controller does: its histories of inputs, outputs, and parameter values.

  • adapt_enabled (bool) – When a Controller has an adapt_fun, that function will only be used when adapt_enabled is set to True.

  • test_interval (float) – The period of time to wait between parameter changes, if an adapt_fun is being used.

get_data() → Dict[str, dict][source]

A method for getting the simulation run data from a Controller.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • a list of the data dicts from each of the controller’s noisemakers, if it has any: data["noises"]

  • the full history of outputs from the controller: data["commands_hist"]

  • the indices of command outputs which are affected by the controller’s noise sources: data["noisemakers_inds"]

  • the full histry of the controller’s parameters: data["params_hist"]

  • the full history of the (sensory) inputs to the controller: data["inputs_hist"]

  • the full history of the controller’s state: data["state_hist"]

Returns:

A dict containing the Controller’s parameters and recorded data, including the data of any NoiseSources which are attached to the controller.

Return type:

dict

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset the controller to its initial state, so that it can be reused without the data and states from a previous simulation run affecting the next run.

You will typically want to get the controller’s data before resetting it, e.g. so that you can store if for the purposes of analysis. The most convenient way to do this will often be to call the get_data_and_reset method defined in the System class.

step(dt: float, inputs: List[float]) → List[float][source]

A method to step a controller forwards in time.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the controller over.

  • inputs (list of floats) – The inputs to the controller.

Returns:

List of commands.

Return type:

list of floats.

RobotController class

class Sandbox_V1_4.RobotController(inputs_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0, state_n: int = 0, initial_state: List[float] = None)[source]

This class represents a controller for an Robot.

In the current implementation, all this class does is wrap Controller with a very slightly smaller init method - see that class for details of any parameters.

__init__(inputs_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0, state_n: int = 0, initial_state: List[float] = None)[source]

This class represents a controller for an Ant.

In the current implementation, all this class does is wrap Controller with a very slightly smaller init method - see that class for details of any parameters.

BeeController class

class Sandbox_V1_4.BeeController(inputs_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0, state_n: int = 0, initial_state: List[float] = None)[source]

This class represents a controller for a Bee.

In the current implementation, all this class does is wrap Controller with a very slightly smaller init method - see that class for details of any parameters.

__init__(inputs_n: int, commands_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0)[source]
Parameters:

  • inputs_n (int) – The number of inputs expected by the controller.

  • commands_n (int) – The number of outputs (commands) that the controller is expected to return from its step method.

  • state_n – The number of state variables that the controller expects to be returned from its step_fun method.

  • initial_state (list[float]) – The controller’s initial state vector, if it has one. Defaults to None. Should be a list with state_n entries.

  • step_fun (a function) – The function which will be used to generate the controller’s outputs, given the inputs to the controller’s step method, the interval of time to integrate over, and any state and parameters the controller makes use of.

  • noisemakers (List of NoiseSource objects.) – A list of noise sources which will potentially affect the commands the controller outputs.

  • noisemaker_inds (List of integers.) – A list of indices of commands which will potentially have noise added to them. Any indices which are out of range in either the list of noisemakers or commands will be ignored.

  • params (list of floats.) – A list of parameters used by the controller. These parameters will be used in the controller’s step_fun function, which will be caused from the controller’s step method.

  • adapt_fun (a function) – A function wich can be used to adapt a controller, by changing its parameters. It only has access to the same data that the controller does: its histories of inputs, outputs, and parameter values.

  • adapt_enabled (bool) – When a Controller has an adapt_fun, that function will only be used when adapt_enabled is set to True.

  • test_interval (float) – The period of time to wait between parameter changes, if an adapt_fun is being used.

FauxKilobotController class

class Sandbox_V1_4.FauxKilobotController(inputs_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0, state_n: int = 0, initial_state: List[float] = None)[source]

This class represents a controller for an FauxKilobot.

__init__(self, inputs_n: int, step_fun: Callable[[float, List[float], List[float], List[float]], List[float]], noisemakers: List[NoiseSource] = None, noisemakers_inds=None, params: List[float] = None, adapt_fun: Callable[[List[float], List[float], List[float]], None] = None, adapt_enabled: bool = True, test_interval: float = 0, state_n: int = 0, initial_state: List[float] = None)[source]
Parameters:

  • inputs_n (int) – The number of inputs expected by the controller.

  • state_n – The number of state variables that the controller expects to be returned from its step_fun method.

  • initial_state (list[float]) – The controller’s initial state vector, if it has one. Defaults to None. Should be a list with state_n entries.

  • step_fun (a function) – The function which will be used to generate the controller’s outputs, given the inputs to the controller’s step method, the interval of time to integrate over, and any state and parameters the controller makes use of.

  • noisemakers (List of NoiseSource objects.) – A list of noise sources which will potentially affect the commands the controller outputs.

  • noisemaker_inds (List of integers.) – A list of indices of commands which will potentially have noise added to them. Any indices which are out of range in either the list of noisemakers or commands will be ignored.

  • params (list of floats.) – A list of parameters used by the controller. These parameters will be used in the controller’s step_fun function, which will be caused from the controller’s step method.

  • adapt_fun (a function) – A function wich can be used to adapt a controller, by changing its parameters. It only has access to the same data that the controller does: its histories of inputs, outputs, and parameter values.

  • adapt_enabled (bool) – When a Controller has an adapt_fun, that function will only be used when adapt_enabled is set to True.

  • test_interval (float) – The period of time to wait between parameter changes, if an adapt_fun is being used.

step(dt: float, inputs: List[float], radio) → List[float][source]

A method to step a controller forwards in time.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the controller over.

  • inputs (list of floats) – The inputs to the controller.

  • radio (Radio) – A Radio. If the controller will use communication with other robots with radios, then it will need to set and receive messages in its step_fun.

Returns:

List of commands.

Return type:

list of floats.
